Award.AwardTitle: Characterizing the Nearest Old Open Cluster: Ruprecht 147
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an observational study of a recently discovered old (~2 Gyr), nearby (~200 pc away) Open Cluster. This cluster?s close proximity means that main sequence stars could be studied to the brown dwarf limit and white dwarfs are also possible. The PI will complete analysis of data already in hand, and data from new observations at optical, ultraviolet and x-ray wavelengths in order to characterize the stellar membership in the cluster. He will also make use of archived data in the literature. Stellar distances will be measured using astrometric observations; activity will be measured from x-ray and optical emission-line spectroscopy and photometry; and cluster membership will be identified from proper motion studies using radial-velocity measurements.

Broader impacts include producing results that are useful to other fields of astronomy, the involvement of a graduate research assistant, and development of a laboratory exercise for introductory astronomy courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Galaxy with respect to the more distant background stars to measure their proper motion (7 years). We also had to wait for binary stars to move in their orbits in order to detect their motion via radial velocity variations. 

Our goal for Ruprecht 147 was to improve empirical techniques for measuring the ages of stars. Sun-like stars spin down over time due to magnetic braking, and this causes magnetic activity to wane as well. We observed this magnetic activity by measuring the brightness of the chromospheres and coronae that are heated by such activity. While it is widely assumed that this activity decays continuously and monotonically over billions of years, this has been inferred from an interpolation between data taken for the young Hyades cluster (600 Myr) and the Sun (4.57 Gyr). We measured chromospheric activity for 70 Sun-like stars of Ruprecht 147 and found that all of its Solar analogs are more active than the Sun, which supports the existence of an activity-age relation. We also measured coronal X-ray activity for some of these stars using Chandra (Saar, Curtis, & Wright 2014). 

K2 observes different patches of sky along the ecliptic in 80-day intervals. We recognized that K2 would point near Ruprecht 147 during its seventh campaign (Oct 4 – Dec 26, 2015). We successfully organized community support for a pointing adjustment and won a NASA Guest Observer proposal (GO 7035, “K2 Survey of Ruprecht 147”) to survey over 1000 candidate members of the cluster. We plan to measure stellar rotation periods for the Sun-like and red dwarf stars in order to calibrate the gyrochronology relationship (i.e., stellar ages from their spin). We also plan to search for transiting super-Earth planets orbiting these stars. Our program represents a tremendous advance for gyrochronology because our survey will reach stars with masses only 40% of the Sun’s, while rotation has only been measured for stars with masses greater than 80% of the Sun’s in other star clusters.

Much of this work was conducted or coordinated by a graduate student under my advisement, Mr. Jason Curtis. I trained Mr. Curtis to write winning grants (e.g., he helped write the NSF AAG proposal that secured this funding, as well as the yearly reports) and observing proposals (e.g., he has authored over a dozen successful observing proposals, which includes proposals to NASA and NOAO); deliver effective oral and poster presentations (e.g., he won the American Astronomical Society’s Chambliss astronomy achievement award, and has delivered 8 professional talks); and mentor students (e.g., he worked with a post-baccalaureate researcher, who presented her research at AAS, is completing a publication for AJ, and has embarked on her own graduate Ph.D. in Astrophysics). In addition to this student training, this program has had a broad impact for other areas of astronomy. The development of a reliable method for measuring the ages of stars is critical for studying the evolution of exoplanet systems, as well as the chemical evolution of the Milky Way (i.e., Galactic Archaeology).
